abstract.p: Jean-Claude Vrinat, owner of Taillevent restaurant in Paris, says he has no plans to follow rival Alain Ducasse to New York City and open another restaurant (S)

block.p: The news of Alain Ducasse's stumbling entrance in the New York restaurant business has been arriving by e-mail and fax to no slight amusement at the leading restaurants back in Paris, his base. Chefs and restaurant owners there are fully familiar with how, at the restaurant bearing his name, Mr. Ducasse has presumed to charge proud New Yorkers far more ($700-plus for two) than any other place in town while seldom making an appearance himself.

Chefs and restaurant owners there are fully familiar with how, at the restaurant bearing his name, Mr. Ducasse has presumed to charge proud New Yorkers far more ($700-plus for two) than any other place in town while seldom making an appearance himself.

At Taillevent, a prime rival in Paris, the owner, Jean-Claude Vrinat, personifies hands-on management as he hovers over teams of waiters and dotes on customers at nearly every meal. During a recent lunch, he paused between fretting about the latest harvest in the Champagne region (should he switch suppliers?) and helping direct a customer to the airport (even having an attendant back the car up a one-way street) to say that no, he was not about to follow Mr. Ducasse across the ocean. ''In New York, I would have to be there,'' Mr. Vrinat said.
Yes, but what about the restaurant he has opened in Tokyo with the French chef Joel Robuchon? No need for him to be hovering there. ''The Japanese do what you tell them,'' he said.
